actors: Holo; Aalborg City; Aalborg University; Nordjyllands Trafikselskab
initiative_description: Aalborg Ost was the site of a 2.1 km driverless route along Astrupstein, the suburb's main arterial road sharing the path with cyclists. Two of these self-driving vehicles are operating simultaneously on the route every day from 7:00 AM to 9:00 PM. The service began in March 2020 and ran for two years until November 2021. Ten wheelchair-accessible stops throughout the historically disadvantaged area-at an assisted living facility, library, and shopping centre, among other locations - expanded access to the existing transit system. The public-private partnership is led by the city and Holo, an AV operator. Following kick off, Aalborg University and transport provider Nordjyllands Trafikselskab conducted a qualitative evaluation of the services impact on peoples everyday lives and the surrounding urban area.

actors: Zemgale Planning Region; Applied Autonomy; EasyMile; Sohjoa Baltic Project
initiative_description: A show case route was run in Aizkraukle. Latvia for two weeks from 9 September 2020. The route was from the Aizkraukle History and Art Museum to L??pl?a Street, a nearby parking lot. The project was mostly financed by the European Union, with the Latvian side providing 15% co-financing. The total cost was over 100,000 euros. This pilot was run as part of the Sohjoa Baltic Project funded by the Interreg - Baltic Sea Region Programme.

An autonomous shuttle was to be piloted on a circular route between Aachen University Hospital and Vaals in the Netherlands. The route covered several kilometers and travelled at speeds up to 30km/h. It was planned that a CM Mission would be used in the pilot. For various technical and safety reasons the pilot did not go ahead. Instead, vehicles were demonstrated at the Aldenhoven Test Centre near to Aachen in March 2020. This pilot was part of the I-AT Interreg Deutschland Nederland (2017-2020) project.

actors: Local Motors; AMS Institute; GVB; City of Amsterdam; Provincie Noord-Holland; Vervoerregio Amsterdam; Bureau Marineterrein
initiative_description: A 3D-printed, autonomous electric vehicle named Olli, was supposed to be operated as part of a trial to test whether self-driving vehicles could be implemented in Amsterdam's logistics infrastructure. The vehicle was to drive across the Marineterrein - a (almost) car-free site on private grounds. The Municipality of Amsterdam, the Amsterdam Transport Region, other partners, and Local Motors, decided to discontinue Olli. After 2 years there was still no indication that two approved vehicles could hit the road in Amsterdam. The manufacturer of Olli, Local Motors, closed operations in January 2022.

actors: Municipality of Appelscha; Easymile; Mayor and Alderman of Appelscha
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle pilot program was conducted in Appelscha Village from September 2016 to November 2016. The shuttle operated on a two-way bike path from the visitor centre Staatsbosbeheer to city of Appelscha . The bike path route was pre-programmed for the Easymile shuttle and was approximately 1.6 miles.

actors: Bad Birnbach market; Rottal-Inn district; Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich; DB Regio Bus Bayern
initiative_description: On-demand autonomous shuttles are being piloted at Bad Birnbach. The shuttles operated 0800-1800 daily and could be booked in advance. This trial is being undertaken as part of the HEAL project.

actors: Regionalbus Ostbayern; DB Regio Bus Region Bayern; ioki; Kurverwaltung der Marktgemeinde Bad Birnbach; LK (District Office) Rottal-Inn; City of Bad Birnbach; Government of Lower Bavaria; Government of Upper Palatinate; Bay State Ministry of the Interior and for Integration; Bayr.State Ministry for Housing, Construction and Transport; EasyMile; TV Sd; Wiss.Comp.: TH Ingolstadt (CARISSMA); University of Wrzburg; TH Degendorf
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was launched into regular service in Bad Birnbach in 2017 by DB Regio Bus Bayern. The initial route of 700m operated from the town centre to the thermal baths on public roads.In October 2019, the autonomous line 7015 went into operation, successfully connecting the station with the center of Bad Birnbach. This new route is 1400 m.

initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Brum. The shuttle ran on a route of 1.5km between the Fornebu S shopping center and the Storya swimming pool. The bus also stoped at the Storya school. Services were offered everyday between 1000 and 1800. The route took about 10 minutes.

actors: BVG (Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe AR); ioki; Berlin Agency for Electromobility (eMO); EasyMile; SenUVK & SenWEB, district office Reinickendorf, Berliner Wasserbetriebe, EasyMile
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles were piloted in Berlin on a 600 m route. The shuttle carried passengers between Alt-Tegel U-Bahn, Am Tegeler Hafen, Wilkestrae and Medebacher Weg.The service operated Mon-Fri from 0730-1100 and 1500-1830, free of charge. On Sat and Sun there were regular journeys between 1030 and 1730. This trial was conducted as part of the See-Meile project.

actors: Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe (BVG); Technical University of Berlin  Center for Technology and Society (ZTG); IKEM (Institute for Climate Protection, Energy, Mobility eV)
initiative_description: Funded by the Federal Ministry for Digital Affairs and Transport.

actors: BVG (Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe AR); Charite Berlin, Berl.SenUVK
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles were piloted on two different campuses in Berlin. The first was a route of 1200m was on Charit Mitte campus. Two additional routes of 800m and 1500m were piloted on the campus of Virchow Klinikum. Pilots at both campuses were undertaken as part of Project STIMULATE.

actors: DB AG; Local Motors; Berlin Agency for Electromobility (eMO)
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles were piloted at the EUREF campus in Berlin-Schneberg in Berlin. The shuttles operated on a 700m route with 3 stops. The  route was shared the road with pedestrians, cyclists, and occasionally with cars and trucks. This trial was conducted as part of the First Mover project.

actors: BVG (Berliner Verkehrsbetriebe AR); ioki; Berlin Agency for Electromobility (eMO); EasyMile; ZDB; Innoz
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles were piloted at the EUREF campus in Berlin-Schneberg in Berlin. This trial was conducted as part of the Pole Position project.

actors: Bernmobil ; EasyMile; Swiss Federal Railways (SBB); Trapeze
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles were piloted in Bern, Switzerland. The service was provide on a 2000m route with 6 stops between  the Brenpark and the funicular 'Marzilibahn'. This trial was conducted by Swiss public transport provider Bernmobil.

actors: RATP Group; Communaut d'Agglomration du Boulonnais (CAB); City of Boulogne-sur-Mer
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was trialled on a 300 m route in Boulogne-sur-Mar. The route covered the centre of Boulogne-sur-Mer and two lines ran on market days allow residents to go shopping without using their cars.The trial was to obtain passenger opinions about how the shuttle might be improved. Information was also collected on performance, reliability and operating safety. The service ran from Wednesday to Sunday from 11.30 a.m. until 6.30 p.m. and was free of charge.
A pilot of an autonomous shuttle was conducted in mixed traffic on public roads in Belgium in 2018. The shuttle travelled a 2.4 km route from Leeuw van Waterloo to Hoeve van Hougoumont.

actors: Universit libre de Bruxelles (ULB); Vrije Universiteit Brussel (VUB)
initiative_description: Researchers at the Francophone and Dutch-speaking Brussels universities (ULB and VUB) conducted a pilot project involving an autonomous shuttle the Brussels Health Campus in Jette. The Brussels Health Campus covers 32 hectares and has hundreds of patients and visitors each day.

actors: Socit des Transports Intercommunaux de Bruxelles (STIB)
initiative_description: A trial of an autonomous shuttle was coordinated by the local public transport operator STIB. The Socit des Transports Intercommunaux de Bruxelles (STIB) provides public transport services in the Brussels Capital Region and its periphery. Two shuttles covered a trajectory of 1.5 km following a fixed-route in a park with five station-based stops in the municipality of Sint-Pieters-Woluwe. The park site allowed for interaction with pedestrians and cyclists. The shuttles operated on Fridays and during the weekends from the end of June until the end of September 2019.

initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was trialled on a private road at EDF's nuclear power plant at Civaux. The shuttle transported staff across the site.

actors: EasyMile; Ligier; Michelin; Universit Clermont Auvergne
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was trialled at the Michelin technological center at Ladoux, Clermont-Ferrand, France.  The vehicle travelled on a 1.4 km long route and had 8 predefined stops. The vehicle was used every day from Monday to Thursday between 7:30 and 15:30 during 3 months (starting in July 2015 to September 2015). More than 300 persons were transported. The mean speed (including stops) was 8 km/h with a maximum speed of 15 km/h in the straight portions of the road. The pilot was conducted as part of the FUI VIPA (Vhicule Individuel Public Autonome)  Fleet project.

actors: EasyMile; Ligier; Michelin; Universit Clermont Auvergne
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was trialled at the Estaing Teaching Hospital in Clermont Ferrand, Clermont-Ferrand, France.  The vehicle travelled on footpath in a very confined area. The pilot was conducted to assess the acceptability of the shuttle. Based on these trials the Ligier Group developed the EasyMile EZ10.

actors: Navya; Republic and Canton of Geneva; University of Geneva; Transport Publics Genevois (TPG)
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was deployed in Contern,an industrial area located around 10km east of Luxembourg City. One NAVYA autonomated minibus operated between the new Sandweiler-Contern train station and the Campus Contern, an office complex in Luxembourg. This service was provided from Monday to Friday during peak hours. It started in 2018, had some operation time in 2020 but had to stop due to road works and changes on the route until being restarted in April 2022 until the end of this same year. The 2.3 km route was shared with industrial vehicles, trucks and individual cars. Contern was one of the pilots demonstrated as part of the AVENUE project.

actors: PH City & Port Development; Homeowners' association rhusgadekvarteret; Region Hovedstaden; Movia; Metroselskabet; AVENUE
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle bus was trialled in the seafront area Nordhavn as part of the EU-funded project AVENUE. The service operated for seven months connecting the residential/business area with parking/metro in Nordhavn.

actors: Bestmile; Transports de la rgion Morges Bire Cossonay
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Cossonay. Shuttles services operated on a 1.7 km route with 8 stops from the funicular station to key attractions in the old town on two different loops.

actors: Jaguar Land Rover; Tata Motors European Technical Centre
initiative_description: Jaguar Land Rover and Tata Motors European Technical Centre demonstrated their self-driving vehicle in Coventry city centre. This required the cars (at a maximum speed of 20 mph) to navigate through a busy mixed use area  taking account of buses, cyclists and pedestrians as well as other cars.

actors: Jaguar Land Rover; Tata Motors European Technical Centre
initiative_description: Jaguar Land Rover and Tata Motors European Technical Centre demonstrated their self-driving systems in Coventry in October 2018 as part of UK Autodrives final multi-vehicle demonstrations. Both sets of cars negotiated mapped stop signs, traffic lights, roundabouts, intersections, and pedestrian crossings.

actors: TU Delft; Metropoolregio Rotterdam Den Haag (MRDH - Rotterdam The Hague Metropolitan Area); Municipality of Delft (Gemeente Delft); Province of Zuid-Holland
initiative_description: The Green Village in Delft was the initial site of the Researchlab Automated Driving Delft (RADD). The research lab open on 27 June 2017. The Green Village was home to various testing conditions including a closed environment (enclosed test site, test track), a semi-closed environment, to testing on public roads and on and around the TU Delft Campus. The centre moved to the Future Mobility Park in September 2021.

actors: Future Mobility Network; TU Delft CITG; Province of Brabant; Municipality of Drimmelen; Arriva Nederland; Spring Innovation Management
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was trialled on a public road alongside the Biesbosch marina. The project involved Arriva, the Drimmelen municipality, Navya, The Future Mobility Network, the province of Noord-Brabant, the West-Brabant region, Breda University of Applied Sciences and TU Delft. The shuttle travelled at a speed of 20 km/h from one end of the marina to the other (approximately 3 kilometers).

actors: Dublin City Council; EasyMile; University College Dublin
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Dublin. The service operated on a 1 k m route from the Dublic Convention Centre to Arena on North Wall Quay. The pilot was conducted as part of Dublin's Smart Docklands project.

An autonomous shuttle is being trialled on an industrial site in Dunkirk. The site is an international training site of Oleum of TOTAL. The 800m route will operate between the guard's post to the training centre.

actors: Stagecoach; Transport Scotland; Alexander Dennis; Fusion Processing Ltd; ESP Group
initiative_description: CAVForth (Connected Autonomous Vehicles) is a pilot scheme based in eastern Scotland to develop passenger-carrying autonomous bus services in the United Kingdom. The scheme's first bus route, the AB1 park and ride service, is operated by Stagecoach East Scotland at a 20-minute frequency between Edinburgh Park and the Ferrytoll Park and Ride site via the Forth Road Bridge. The pilot scheme was set to commence passenger-carrying service as early as mid-2020, however delays due to the COVID-19 pandemic would see the first trials of five Enviro200AVs limited to 50mph (80km/h) along the CAVForth1 route take place over two weeks in April 2022. The first passenger-carrying trials of the CAVForth Enviro200AVs took place in January 2023. The service commenced public operations on 15 May 2023. The bus is built to SAE Level 4 requirements, meaning a driver is present in the bus at all times but does not need to control the bus in regular service.

actors: GreenTEC; Sylter Verkehrsgesellschaft; EurA; Autokraft; Fastleansmart; Interlink; MOTEG; CAU zu Kiel
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles were piloted in Enge-Sande. Tests were conducted on private premises at the Green TEC Campus and on public roads on the North Sea island of Sylt. The shuttle travelled on a 1.5 mile route on the Green TEC campus. The pilots were part of the NAF-Bus project.

initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was trialled in Espoo, Finland from October 2017-November 2017. The shuttle ran along a 700m route between Otaniemi underground station and campus of Aalto University in Otaniemi business district.

actors: Sensible 4; Nokia; City of Espoo; Aalto University
initiative_description: A GACHA autonomous shuttle bus equipped with Sensible4's self-driving technology was piloted as part of the LuxTurrim5G ecosystem. It was tested on Nokia's campus.

address: Fontevraud, Pays de la Loire, France
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was trialled at the Royal Abbey of Our Lady of Fontevroad, France. The shuttle operated on a 500 m route between the ticket office and the hotel car park with several stops at points of interest around the Abbey. The aim of the shuttle is to improve accessibility for people with mobility difficulties.

actors: Stadtwerke Verkehrsgesellschaft Frankfurt am Main mbH (VGF); Continental; EasyMile
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted on the campus of the University of Applied Sciences in Frankfurt. The short-term pilot offered students and staff rides on private campus grounds. The pilot was part of the CUBe (Contiental Urban Mobility Experience) project.

Two autonomous shuttles were trialled at Frankfurt Airport under two different sets of conditions. First, the shuttles operated on a 1.5-kilometer road in partnership with Fraport Group. Second, the shuttles will be trialled at the end of the day on public roads. Rides in the shuttle were only offered to airport employees. The test phase and launch of the two vehicles took place on 27 October 2018.

actors: Transports publics fribourgeois (TPF); Marly Innovation Center (MIC); Municipality of Marly; Agglomeration of Fribourg; State of Fribourg
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Fribourg. Shuttles services operated on a 1.3 km route with 4 stops from Marly Innovation Centre to Fribourg Public Transport network. The shuttle ran Monday to Friday during peak hours (0630-0900; 1130-1330; 1630-1830).

actors: EasyMile; Gda?sk City Hall; Municipal Office of Gda?sk; Gda?sk Road and Greenery Administration; The Public Transport Authority in Gda?sk; Gda?sk Buses and Trams Company; Sohjoa Baltic Project
initiative_description: An EasyMile EZ10 autonomous shuttle bus was trialled in Gdansk from 07 Sep-30 Sep 2019. The shuttle ran seven days a week, twice an hour, and for five hours a day (1000-1500). The service was provided free of charge and ran along Karwienska Street. The route was from the stop at the entrance to the Zoo, through an intermediate stop at the car park, and to the final stop at Spacerowa Street and back. The vehicle will move along the pre-programmed route, but the operator will be present on board to react in the event of an emergency. One ride lasted up to 15 minutes. The contractor trained three experienced drivers of Gdansk Buses and Trams company to act as operators. This pilot was run as part of the Sohjoa Baltic Project funded by the Interreg - Baltic Sea Region Programme.

actors: TPG (Transports publics genevois), MobileThinking, BestMile; IOKI, Certh, University of Geneva
initiative_description: After the autonomous shuttle service in Meyrin was ended in February 2020. A new service was started on the the Belle-Ide Estate, which is situated within a medical/psychiatric medical facility in Thnex, a nearly 15,000 inhabitants peri-urban commune in the Geneva area. This hospital is part of the Geneva University Hospital (HUG), which is committed to the development of green mobility initiatives. This new demonstration was set up in spring 2020, and remained in operation beyond the end of the AVENUE project. The service was operated in open, mixed traffic roads. The solution is end-to-end operator-free, from depot door opening at the start of the service to the end. The service operates day and night, and under diverse weather conditions, serving 70 virtual stops covering the entire 38hectares domain from Monday to Friday from 0800 to 2200.

actors: TPG (Transports publics genevois), Padam, MobileThinking, Certh, University of Geneva
initiative_description: The target of the Geneva site is to integrate automated on-demand vehicles with the existing public transport services. At the Belle-Ide Estate, located close to the French border and which consists of a 38 acres area, different facilities including a hospital, kindergarten, conference center, and restaurants. To better connect these facilities, this deployment site will see three automated vehicles providing a 100% on-demand and electric services to passengers. There will be no fixed routes and no timetables; passengers can book and tailor their ride via a dedicated application.

actors: Municipality of Gjesdal; Navya; Forum Virium Helsinki; Helsinki Metropolia University of Applied Sciences
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles were piloted in Gjesdal, a small municipality close to Stavanger, Norway. The Municipality of Gjesdal hosted two pilots in the center of lgrd. The first was run by Saga consortium in the summer of 2020 and the second is executed by Sensible4-Shotl consortium during the winter of 2020-2021. The Saga Consortium  has four partners: Mobility Forus, Halogen and Ramboll Management Consulting from Norway together with Spare Labs from Canada. The pilot route runs between residential detached house area located on top of a hill and a commercial area located in a valley, serving local shoppers and school kids. The route included street side parking, turning left and right, one roundabout, a pedestrian bridge and 14 crossings with pedestrians. There are no traffic lights on the route. This pilot was part of the FABULOS pre-commercial procurement project.

An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Gjvik. The shuttle ran on a ring route of 300m from Fjellhallen to centre of Gjvik (Storgata via vre Torvgate) and made three scheduled stops. The municipality experienced three gearbox failures in just a short time. After the third accident, they canceled the pilot project.

actors: Stagecoach; Transport Scotland; Alexander Dennis; Fusion Processing Ltd; ESP Group
initiative_description: Bus manufacturers Alexander Denniss was trialled in Glasgow at the CAV Scotland conference at the SEC Centre in November 2019. The vehicle is a full-size, single-decker bus. The prototype travelled around the SEC car park during the autonomous vehicle trade show. These trials were conducted as part of the the CAVForth pilot which received 4.35million in part funding from the UK Government's Centre for Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CAV).

actors: Holo;RISE; Chalmers; Chalmers Fastigheter; Gteborgs Stads Parkering; lvstranden Utveckling AB; Karlastaden Utveckling; Ericsson; Sunfleet; Gteborgs Stad Trafikkontoret; Frvaltnings; Framtiden; Vsttrafik; Gteborgs Stad Stadsbyggnadskontoret; Hrryda Kommun
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles were piloted at Chalmers University of Technology and at Lindholmen Science Park. In the first phase, shuttles were operated in the Chalmers area from May-December 2018. The service was primarily used by students of and visitors to the campus. In the second phase, shuttles were piloted from 24 April-22 November 2019. The shuttle was free and operate from Polstjrnegatan, down Stenbocksgatan, Gamla Ceresgatan, Plejadgatan, Lrdomsgatan, Diagonalen and back again.

Volvo has developed a self-driving electric bus. Together with transport company Keolis, Volvo has launched a project to test this new prototype. During this early stage, the self-driving feature will be used to set up bus circulation in parking bays, which will save time for drivers on waiting for their bus to be washed and prepared for their next trip.

actors: Ruter; Norwegian Public Roads Administration; Urban Environment Agency in Oslo Municipality; TI  Institute of Transport Economics; Cicero; Holo; MobileEye
initiative_description: Initially operated as metro feeder service, the site in Groruddalen will deploy automated shuttles as competitive service fully integrated with other traffic, serving passengers in the area in their everyday mobility needs.The test activities will take place in Groruddalen ('Grorud Valley') located north-east of Oslo city center. The valleys residential areas were developed as 'satellite cities' with large apartment complexes separated by green areas, with a local offer of schools, shops, and leisure opportunities.

actors: Daimler; Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment; Province of North Holland; Municipality of Haarlem; Municipality of Haarlemmermeer; Vialis
initiative_description: A largely self-driving bus drove on the bus lane between Schiphol and Haarlem. The bus communicates with traffic lights  and there was a safety driver on board, to intervene if necessary. The test was a collaboration between the German Daimler, the Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment, the province of North Holland as road manager and owner of the bus lane, the municipalities of Haarlem and Haarlemmermeer and Vialis as a partner in traffic technology.

actors: Hamburger Hochbahn AG; DLR Institute for Transport System Technology, Freie und Hansestad Hamburg (BWVI); hySOLUTIONS; IAV; IKEM, Siemens Mobility; Hochbahn
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Hamburg's HafenCity on two different routes. The Ring route operated along  the streets Am Dalmannkai, Groer Grasbrook, Am Sandtorkai and Am Sandtorpark. The second route operated on  Am Kaiserkai and drive directly past Hamburgs new landmark Elbe Philharmonic Hall. The final route was 1.8 km with five stops. The pilot was undertaken as part of the HEAT project (Hamburg Electric Autonomous Transportation).

actors: Keolis; Navya; Belgian Ministry of Mobility; Vias Institute (Belgium Road Safety Institute); Domaine of Han
initiative_description: A pilot of a Navya autonomous shuttle was run by Keolis in partnership with Navya, Belgian Ministry of Mobility, Vias Institute (Belgium Road Safety Institute), and Domaine of Han. The shuttle drove in normal traffic conditions on a 500m route in the Cave Domaine of Han-sur-Lesse before being extended to cover a 1.5km route.

actors: Metropolia University of Applied Sciences; Forum Virium Helsinki
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was trialled as part of the Sohjoa Baltic Project in Suvilahti. The shuttle ran from the gate of Suvilahti cultural centre via Stadin Panimo to Srnisten rantatie. The shuttle operated in mixed traffic and in narrow alleys, without clear road traffic driving lines.

A fleet of three autonomous vehicles (AVs), including a GACHA shuttle bus designed by Muji, were piloted in Pasila, Helsinki from 14 April 2020-30 June 2020. The AVs drove along a circular route in Eastern Pasila, going from the Pasila station next to the Mall of Tripla, then turning north to circle back to Messukeskus Fair centre. The Pasila route ran around a large block consisting of offices and housing, together with several public services and authorities. The buses drove partly on a separate lane with speeds of up to 40 km/h. The route included several crossroads with traffic lights, right turns, street side parking and a roundabout. There were three bus stops on the route (Pasila station, Messukeskus Fair center and Asemanplliknkatu street). On-demand rides were facilitated from existing bus stops via the Shotl App and service. The fleet were operated and monitored from a Remote Control Centre (RCC).  Due to Covid-19 passengers were only allowed onboard from 9 June onwards. The pilot was part of the EU-funded FABULOS project (Pre-Commercial Procurement of Future autonomous bus urban level Operation Systems).

actors: Metropolia University of Applied Sciences; Forum Virium Helsinki
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was trialled as part of the Sohjoa Baltic Project in Helsinki, Finland. The shuttle ran twice an hour, between  to 15 on weekdays and between 12 to 18 on weekends. One trip around the route takes approximately 20 minutes. The route and stops were equivalent to the 90R, from the foothills of the Vuosaari metro station to Aurinkolahti beach and back.

actors: Metropolia University of Applied Sciences; City of Helsinki; European Union
initiative_description: In 2018, RobobusLine started in the Kivikko district. The 1 km route had two stops and ran from Kivikko's sport park to bus stop Kivikontie. The operation of the route encountered technical problems and the experiment was suspended before the scheduled time. On line 94R, the robot bus did not yet get along adequately in relation to other traffic: the intersections required human intervention, and the buss slow pace prompted other drivers to overtake, resulting in sudden braking. The mechanics of the bus itself also encountered various problems due to the Finnish climate.

actors: Metropolia University of Applied Sciences; City of Helsinki
initiative_description: The second Robobus test line number 26R ran in 2019 between the Redi shopping center in Kalasatama and Isoisnsilta. Boarding during the trial period was free of charge. Robobus was in operation on weekdays from 0900 to 1455, driving along a route with three stops: Redi, Polariksenkatu and Isoisnsilta.

An autonomous shuttle was trialled as part of the Sohjoa Baltic Project in Helsinki's Hernesaari district. The shuttle ran along a 500m route from sauna/restaurant to other restaurants and had 4 stops.

An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Issy-les-Moulineaux. The shuttle operated on a 600 m circuit in Ile Saint-Germain Park between the car park and the T2 tram. The trial was part of So Mobility project funded by the 'Grand Paris de la Mobilite' (Greater Paris Mobility) Initiative

actors: Zemgale Planning Region; Applied Autonomy; EasyMile; Sohjoa Baltic Project
initiative_description: This short term show case route ran for two weeks from 14 August 2020. The route ran on Pasta Island, a multifunctional place for recreational, cultural and social activities. The area is for pedestrians, but the robot bus will drive there with special permits. The autonomous bus has six seats and will have two stops on the Pasta Island  Tea House and Swimming place. The project was mostly financed by the European Union, with the Latvian side providing 15% co-financing. The total cost was over 100,000 euros. This pilot was run as part of the Sohjoa Baltic Project funded by the Interreg - Baltic Sea Region Programme.

Autonomous shuttles were trialled as part of the 2018 FIFA World Cup. The shuttles were trialled at the Group C fixture between France and Australia. The service travelled on a 650 m route from Kazan's fan zone meeting point, along a dedicated road empty of other traffic and surrounded by a light fence to keep away pedestrians and animals. The shuttle stopped well before the Kazan Arena (since renamed Ak Bars Arena). The trial was supported by the Russian Government as part of a push into autonomous vehicles.

actors: Movia; Region Sjlland; Region Hovedstaden; Metroselskabet
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle bus was trialled both inside the SUH Kge and in the areas surrounding the Slagelse Hospital. The pilot was part of a collaboration between Movia, Region Sjlland, Region Hovedstaden and Metroselskabet. The shuttles were piloted in the lobby of Sjllands Universitetshospital Kge, an area with a lot of pedestrians. The service drove passengers from SUH Koge to and from the nearest train station.

actors: Kongsberg municipality; Norwegian Public Roads Administration; Public Transport Authority for Viken (Ruter); EasyMile; Brakar; Institute of Transport Economics (TI); Forum Virum Helsinki
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Kongsberg. The shuttle started regular services on Route 450 in April 2019 (off-peak hours) after testing from October 2018. Later the autonomous service was extended to afternoon rush hours and a shorter route on Saturdays. From September 2020, the service was provided using a new Generation 3 bus with improved lidar-sensors. Due to the COVID-19, route 450 was paused for two periods, one of them for as long as six months. The the final route was a 4.4km stretch of road from the center to the Kongsberg Technology park. This pilot was run as part of the Sohjoa Baltic Project funded by the Interreg - Baltic Sea Region Programme.

An autonomous shuttle was trialled in Koppl, a village 10 km east of from the City of Salzburg. The shuttle operated on a 1.4km public road. The centre of the village is 1.4km from the major bus line connecting the village with the city centre. The pilot involved two phases.  Firstly, the shuttle was deployed on a short route with a total length of about 400 m and a driving time of approximately 5 min. This short route in the village centre guaranteed a fast setup and immediate testing. The long route has a length of 1.4 km (one-way), thus driving the whole route with 2.8 km takes approximately 20 min (at a maximum speed of 16 km/h including stops and slow driving manoeuvres). Beside the start and end stops, the route includes two additional bus stops for each driving direction.

The vehicle moved along a pre-programmed route, but an operator was present to react in the event of an emergency. The operators were students from Tallinn University of Technology who passed the two-week training organized by Holo. This pilot was run as part of the Sohjoa Baltic Project funded by the Interreg - Baltic Sea Region Programme.

actors: Milrem; EasyMile; Guardtime; Tallin City; Estonian Ministry of Economic Affairs
initiative_description: A pilot of EasyMile autonomous shuttles was carried out in Tallinn as part of the Estonian presidency of the European Union. The pilot took place between 29 July-31 August 2017. The service was operated on a limited route between the Mere puiestee (Mere Avenue) stop and Tallinn Creative Hub. The service ran Mon-Sat, from 0830-1730. An operator, whose presence is compulsory according to the Traffic Code, was be present on each bus to explain the driverless technology to passengers. The pilot project cost approximately 100,000, two-thirds of which was covered by private-sector partners.

An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Tallin's western Mustame district on a pre-mapped 1.8km circuit. The serivce was free and ran Tuesday to Sunday between 1000-1600. The shuttle route passed nearby apartment buildings, bus and trolleybus stops, and the Mustame health centre. There was always a security person on the bus who will monitor the safety of each manoeuvre and intervene if necessary.

actors: Mobile Civitatem Consortium; Modern Mobility; Tallinn University of Technology; AuVeTech; Fleet Complete
initiative_description: A pilot of an ISEAUTO shuttle was conducted in Tallin between June 2020 and September 2020. The shuttle is a prototype developed by Tallinn Univeristy of Technology and Auve Tech. The shuttle was piloted on a 2.4 km long route between Tallinn Ulemiste City E-Estonia Briefing Centre to the International Aiprot and from there to a Ulemiste shopping centre. The speed limit was up to 30 km/h on most of the route but one stretch of 500 m from the shopping mall to the airport was up to 50 km/h. The route included both right and left turns. The lemiste City quarter has mixed traffic including pedestrians and cyclists at low speed. The shuttle operated in self-driving mode in the vast majority of situations while the option to manually override remained to assist in difficult or preferable circumstances. The shuttles were monitored by human operators remotely by using novel 5G technology. The pilot was part of the EU-funded FABULOS project (Pre-Commercial Procurement of Future autonomous bus urban level Operation Systems).

An autonomous shuttle was trialled in Tampere, Finland as part of the EU-funded project SHOW. Two self-driving Toyota Proace mini-buses were converted into autonomous vehicles by the Finnish self-driving technology company Sensible 4. The vehicles acted as feeder services for the first tramline in the city. The shuttle followed a 3.5 km long route clockwise with 10 bus stops. The pilot was designed to support the development and launch of Dawn, Sensible 4s unique all-weather full-stack autonomous driving software.

actors: Tampere University of Technology; Finnish Transport Agency; Finnish Transport Safety Agency Trafi
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was trialled in Tampere, Finland. The shuttle ran along a 500m route between in the Hervant district. The route ran from the Tampere University of Technology campus to the Shopping Centre Duo.
A pilot of an autonomous shuttle took place on 13 November 2019 as part of a networking meeting for trade visitors. The testing took place during winter. This trial was part of the Digibus project.
An autonomous shuttle was trialled in The Hague. The HagaShuttle travels back and forth on a 1km route from the Haga Hospital to the 'Leyweg' bus stop.

An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Toulouse. The shuttle operated on a 850m route with 3 stops. The route was within a pedestrianised zone and followed the Allees Jules Guesdes from Palais de Justice Metro/Tram station to Grand-Round public garden.

actors: Municipality of Trikala; e-Trikala S.A.; Institute of Communication and Computer Systems (ICCS); Hellenic Ministry of Infrastructure; Transport and Networks; Robosoft; Region of Thessaly and the Greek Police
initiative_description: Six autonomous shuttles were trialled on a 2.4-kilometer (1.5-mile) route in mixed traffic with pedestrians, bicycles and cars. The route had 8 stops and the service was availabe to the public between Nov 2015 until Feb 2016.The route linked the city centre with the central business district. A dedicated asphalt lane was constructed for the shuttle, with 70 on-street parking spaces being removed. A bus control centre was set up in the city, in order for technicians to supervise the respective routes, while an appropriately trained 'operator' was on board in every bus to intervene in the case of a possible vehicles loss of control. Trikala was one of seven cities were autonomous shuttles were demonstrated as part of the CityMobil2 project.

actors: Local Motors; ITC-ILO; Reale Mutua; University of Turin; Turin Municipality
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Turin. The service operated for four months inside the ITC-ILO campus. Turin was one of the winners of Local Motors' Olli Fleet Challenge, a contest between European cities to determine the best short-term urban use case for testing the self-driving shuttle.

actors: City of Vantaa; Helsinki Region Transport; Finnish Transport Agency; Finnish Transport Safety Agency Trafi; Helsinki-Uusimaa Regional Council
initiative_description: Four autonomous shuttles were piloted in Kivist, Vantaa, Finland from 10 July - 9 August  2015. The service transported people from the new Kivist Railway Station to an exhibition area where the annual 2015 Housing Fair was held. The service was nonstop on a 0.53 mile, fully segregated and fenced lane. The trial participants were the City of Vantaa, Helsinki Region Transport, the Finnish Transport Agency, the Finnish Transport Safety Agency Trafi and the Helsinki-Uusimaa Regional Council. Vantaa was one of seven cities were the shuttles were demonstrated as part of the CityMobil2 project.

actors: Municipality of Skellefte; EasyMile; Swedish Transport Administration; Vinnova
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles were piloted in the municipality of Skellefte. The pilot was overseen by the municipality in partnership with the Swedish Transport Administration and Vinnova. The shuttles were tested in the village of Varutrsk outside Skellefte. Varutrsk was identified as a good place to test as it is a reasonable distance from the village to road 95 where the regional bus passes. The municipal board's working committee in Skellefte decided on Tuesday that the municipality will invest two million kroner in the project. The remaining twelve million kroner are covered by the Swedish Transport Administration and Vinnova.

An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Velizy over the summer of 2018. The shuttle operated on Villacoublay Air Base. Test rides were provided in June and July and September the shuttle was used to transport airmen from operational zones to the living zone.

An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Velizy. The shuttle operated on 4000 m route in mixed traffic (motorists; bicyclists; trams). The route was from Mozart and Le Clos neighbourhoods to the R. Wagner T6 station. The road network was equipped with sensors, allowing MILLA to detect priorities on the right, traffic light, pedestrian crossings. The shuttle could be hailed via an app. An opinion survey of users was conducted. The MILLApod shuttle was designed by Intelligent Systems for Mobility (ISFM)

actors: Transdev; EasyMile; City of Verdun; Grand Est Local Authority
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Verdun. The shuttle operated on a 1400 m route with 5 stops in the city centre.

Three autonomous shuttles were trialled in the communes of of Vernon and Giverny, Normandy, in the north of France. The shuttles operated on a 12 km round-trip route connecting a museum site (Claude Monet Foundation and Impressionist Museum) in rural France with the Vernon train station.
An autonomous shuttle was piloted at Versailles. The shuttle operated on a 1000 m route from Cite des cadres bus stop to Les Allees des Maronniers

actors: Wiener Linien; AIT; KFV; TV Austria; Siemens Mobility; Navya
initiative_description: A pilot of a Navya autonomous shuttle was carried out in Seestadt, Vienna as part of the auto.Bus - Seestadt research project. The shuttle service had ten fixed stops along the approximately 2km route around the Seestadt U2 station. An attempt was made to travel the planned route regularly Monday to Friday (weekdays) from 0800 to 1200. Seestadt was selected because the route was deemed less complex than routes in the city center and because Urban Lakeside is an innovative living environment, an 'urban lab'. The Seestadt research project ran from 01 August 2017 until 23 June 2021.

actors: Technische Universiteit Delft; Wageningen University; EasyMile
initiative_description: The province of Gelderland in the Netherlands piloted two selfdriving vehicles (with no steering wheel or pedals) in the FoodValley region between Ede/Wageningen railway station and Wageningen University and Research centre (WUR) and on the WUR campus. The pilot was part of the the Citymobil2 project which aimed to demonstrate autonomous vehicles on public roads, with a steward on board. The WEpods project operated on public roads in mixed traffic. A control room monitored vehicle operation and safety, and initially a steward may accompany the guests in the vehicle. WEpods operated initially on a fixed route.

initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles (WEPods) were piloted at Weeze Airport, Germany. The route of a few hundred meters started at Weeze Airport Departure Hall and then stopped at the parking lot and airport hotel. The pilot was conducted with involvement of over 20 Dutch and German organisations including municipalities and its subsidiaries, launching the first autonomous driving shuttle in Nordrhein-Westfalen with a budget of 8.5 million euros. This pilot was part of the I-AT Interreg Deutschland Nederland (2017-2020) project.

A pilot of autonomous shuttles took place on Wiener Strae between Hauptplatz and St. Peter an der Sperr, at the Lower Austrian State Exhibition 'World in motion' in the centre of Wiener Neustadt. The route was 560 metres and the vehicles operated Tuesday until Saturday from 10:00 am to 12:00 pm and from 1:00 pm to 3:00 pm. This trial was part of the Digibus project.

actors: TU Berlin; TU Dresden; Northwest Brandenburg; District of Ostprignitz-Ruppin; Hffermann Transportsysteme; Office AutoBus; IGES Institute
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Wusterhausen/Dosse. The service was provided from the historic town centre to the train station and supermarket. The route was 3.5km in total in mixed traffic. The pilot was conducted as part of the AutoNV_OPR (Autonomer ffentlicher Nahverkehr im lndlichen Raum (Landkreis Ostprignitz-Ruppin)) project.

actors: SBB; Bestmile; EasyMile; Tech Cluster Zug; Zugerland Verkehrsbetriebe; Mobility Cooperative; City of Zug
initiative_description: An autonomous shuttle was piloted in Zug. Shuttle services operated from Zug railway station to the Technology Cluster Zug. The shuttle was tested as part of the MyShuttle project which ran from 2017-2019 and was funded by the Federal Department of Roads (FEDRO/(Bundesamt fr Strassen  ASTRA)).

actors: Belfast Harbour; EE Automotive; Angoka; BT; Horiba Mira
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles will be piloted in Belfast. The shuttles will operate in Harbour Estate from the Titanic Quarter Railway Station to Thompson Dock in Queen's Island. The service will transport residents, visitors and employees to venues such as Titanic Belfast, Catalyst and Belfast Metropolitan College. The launch of the service is planned for last quarter of 2024. The operation of the shuttle will also support Belfast Harbours delivery of a Strategic Transport Masterplan for Queens Island.  The pilot will be part of a Project Harlander, funded by the Centre for Connected and Autonomous Vehicles Connected and Automated Mobility programme.

address: Sunderland, North East England, United Kingdom
actors: City of Sunderland; Angoka; Aurrigo; Bal Communications; Newcastle University; Stagecoach; Sunderland City Council; Swansea University
initiative_description: An autonomous teleoperated zero-emission passenger mobility service will be trialled in Sunderland. The trial will aim to connect  the University of Sunderland City Campus and Sunderland Royal Hospital, via an Intelligent Transport Corridor (ITC). The trial aligns with the nine principles of the Future of Mobility Urban Strategy and Sunderland's City Plan. The pilot will be part of the SAMS (Sunderland Advanced Mobility Shuttle) Project, funded by the Centre for Connected and Autonomous Vehicles Connected and Automated Mobility programme.

address: Cambridge_UK, East of England, United Kingdom
actors: Greater Cambridge Partnership, Conigital, Gamma, IPG Automotive, dRISK, Stagecoach
initiative_description: On-demand, self-driving vehicles will be trialled in Cambridge. The vehicles will integrate with existing transport services at Cambridge University's West Cambridge Campus and the Cambridge Biomedical Campus. The 12-month trial will be undertaken in a phased manner, initially with engineers providing on-board supervision, migrating to trained operators and culminating in a final phase with only remote operators. The pilot will be part of the Project Connector, funded by the Centre for Connected and Autonomous Vehicles Connected and Automated Mobility programme.

address: Cambridge_UK, East of England, United Kingdom
actors: Greater Cambridge Partnership; Smart Cambridge; Aurrigo
initiative_description: Autonomous shuttles were trialled on the University of Cambridge West Cambridge site from April 2021 until the end of June 2021. The shuttle ran from the Madingley Park & Ride around the University of Cambridges West Cambridge campus. The trial was part of a workstream of the Greater Cambridge Partnership, awarded 3.2milllion of Government funding from the Centre for Connected and Autonomous Vehicles (CCAV), and Innovate UK.

actors: Conigital; WMG; NEC Birmingham; Direct Line Group; Coventry City Council; Solihull Metropolitan Borough Council; Coventry University; dRisk; IPG Automotive; West Midlands Combined Authority
initiative_description: A mixed fleet of 13 self-driving vehicles will be moving passengers and light freight (e.g., mail and parcels for delivery) between Birmingham International Rail Station and Birmingham Business Park, and between Coventry railway station and Coventry University campus. The project will look to establish a self-driving vehicle operation underpinned by a centralised, Remote Monitoring Teleoperation (RMTO) centre.

actors: SAGE Automation; Local Motors; Department for Infrastructure and Transport (Government of South Australia); City of Holdfast Bay
initiative_description: SAGE Automation, Local motors, DPTI and Holdfast Bay will trial a 10-passenger driverless shuttle (Olli) on the beachfront at Glenelg before next summer, taking people 1km and back to Adelaide-designed and built automated stops at Moseley Square and the Broadway Kiosk. Glenelgs Olli will take passengers from the tram stop at Moseley Square along the shared path to the Broadway Kiosk and back. So-called Olli Stops at either end of the line, developed in Adelaide, will be linked using IBM Watson interface technology with interactive displays, and allow for wheelchair-bound passengers. The project is partly funded by the Government of South Australia's Future Mobility Lab Fund.

actors: Flinders University; RAA; Cohda Wireless; Renewal SA; SAGE Automation; SIEMENS, Telstra, UPG; ZENEnergy; Keolis Downer; Marion City Council; Department for Infrastructure and Transport (Government of South Australia)
initiative_description: Flinders University received $4 million from the fund for a five-year driverless shuttle project, which will also utilise Navya vehicles. Run in partnership with the RAA, Cohda Wireless, Renewal SA, SAGE Automation, SIEMENS, Telstra, UPG, ZENEnergy and Keolis Downer, the trial will work towards putting driverless shuttles on public roads within the Tonsley precinct and connecting them to nearby bus stops on South Road and Clovelly Park train station. The project will include the development of a mobile app, so people arriving by bus or train to Tonsley can book a shuttle to meet them. FLEX operated on weekdays between 10am to 2pm.

actors: Aurrigo; Regional Development Australia; Elliot Gardens Retirement Living Village;  Department for Infrastructure and Transport (Government of South Australia)
initiative_description: Tech company Aurrigo  trialled how their Zero Pod, Elliot the Pod, can support the mobility of residents at Elliot Gardens Retirement Village in South Australia. The trial was supported by the Government of South Australia Department of Planning, Transport & Infrastructure (DPTI), and the Alexandrina Council, as part of the South Australian Governments Future Mobility Lab Fund. Elliot was available on various routes Monday to Friday 9am  4pm (excluding public holidays) throughout the village to make accessing the pod easier for residents.  To take a ride, residents could hail Elliot at the community centre or when it was passing, by SMS or phone.

actors: EasyMile; City of Playford; SAGE Automation; Department of Infrastructure, Planning and Logistics (Government of South Australia)
initiative_description: A joint project between the City of Playford, EasyMile, SAGE Automation and Department of Infrastructure, Planning and Logistics (Government of South Australia). The trial saw an autonomous shuttle bus carry passengers between the Muno Para Railway Station to the Playford Alive Township and facilities. The trial was supported by the South Australian Governments Future Mobility Lab Fund.

actors: EasyMile; City of Playford; SAGE Automation; Department of Infrastructure, Planning and Logistics (Government of South Australia)
initiative_description: EasyMile conducted an on-road autonomous vehicle trial in the City of Playford between the old GM carpark and the Lyell McEwin hospital. The trial was supported by a $350,000 State Government grant.

actors: Transport for NSW; Armidale Regional Council; EasyMile; The University of New England; Edwards Coaches; Transdev; WSP
initiative_description: The Armidale Region Driverless Initiative (ARDi), was a partnership between Transport for NSW, Armidale Regional Council, EasyMile, Transdev, WSP, UNE, QBE and Edwards Buses. The trial ran for 12 months in two phases, using a fully automated EasyMile shuttle with capacity to carry up to 14 passengers. The first phase ran between 21 Feb-30 Jun 2019. The shuttle ran on the UNE Campus loop connecting residential colleges with key points across campus. The second phase ran between Aug-Dec 2019. This covered a loop between Armidale CBD and the New England Regional Art Museum (NERAM).

actors: Royal Automobile Club Western Australia (RAC WA); City of Busselton; Western Australian Government
initiative_description: The Royal Automobile Club of Western Australia (RAC) is trialling its driverless electric shuttle bus in the seaside town of Busselton. The buss route goes east from Foreshore Parade and along Geographe Bay Road to the Busselton Volunteer Marine Rescue Centre.

actors: EasyMile; Cairns Regional Council; TransDev; Telstra
initiative_description: Cairns Regional Council hosted a trial of EasyMile's EZ10 shuttle along the Esplanade. French manufacturer EasyMile is showcasing the driverless bus in several cities across Australia. The trial in Cairns took place between 4-8 December. This was part of the 2017/18 Australian Driverless Roadtrip.

actors: Illawara Retirement Trust (IRT) Group; EasyMile; Telsta
initiative_description: The IRT Group, an aged care provider, is trialling EasyMile's EZ10 autonomous shuttle for two weeks at its Kangara Waters retirement village in Canberra. The vehicle will follow an eight stop loop and can carry up to eight passengers. quantitative and qualitative data will be collected throughout the trial to measure perception shifts and behavioural changes of participating residents. The data collected will be shared with government and industry bodies to assist in the development of public policy surrounding the use of autonomous vehicle technologies in an aged care and retirement living settings. The project is partially funded by Telstra.

EasyMile in partnership with TransDev and Telstra offered members of the public free rides on the EZ10 shuttle bus in Petrie Plaza between 23 and 27 November. This was part of the 2017/18 Australian Driverless Roadtrip.

actors: EasyMile; TransDev; Telstra; Redland City Council
initiative_description: EasyMile in partnership with TransDev and Telstra offered members of the public free rides on the EZ10 shuttle along Middle Street at Cleveland Market. This took place on March 4 2018. This was part of the 2017/18 Australian Driverless Roadtrip.

actors: EasyMile; Darwin Waterfront Corporation; Department of Infrastructure, Planning and Logistics
initiative_description: The Driverless Bus Trial was an undertaking between the Department of Infrastructure, Planning and Logistics (DIPL) and Darwin Waterfront Corporation (DWC) to realise the commitment of the Northern Territory Government to deploy and explore automated vehicle technology for passenger transport in a range of different operating environments in the Territory. The bus operated in both on-road and pedestrian environments in three stages within the Darwin Waterfront Precinct and Central Business District.

EasyMile in partnership with TransDev and Telstra offered members of the public free rides on the EZ10 shuttle around a pre-determined continuous loop around car-parks, terminal and hotels at the Darwin Airport. This took place between 21 and 22 February 2018. This was part of the 2017/18 Australian Driverless Roadtrip.

actors: Royal Automobile Club of Tasmania (RACT); City of Hobart; Tasmanian Climate Change Office
initiative_description: The City of Hobart partnered with the Tasmanian Government and RACT to bring a driverless electric bus (DEB) to Hobart to demonstrate the technology and to explore how it may be used in years to come. The vehicle operated from the Sandy Bay Sailing Club and travelled a set route that has been mapped out by the vehicles software. The demonstration ran from 6-13 December 2019. The Lower Sandy Bay was selected for the demonstration as there are lots of trees and buildings in the area for DEB to map and navigate from and it was also a lower-traffic area, as the trial aimed to cause as little impact as possible on peoples daily lives.

actors: Ipswich City Council; EasyMile; TransDev; Telstra
initiative_description: Ipswich City Council trialled one of EasyMile's driverless shuttle buses around its Orion water theme park lagoon near the Orion Shopping Centre on John Nugent Drive at Springfield, near Ipswich. The loop is about 5 minutes long. Ipswich's mayor Andrew Antoniolli commented that: 'The demonstration of this driverless technology is a long-term transport prospect and one we are certainly investigating. The demonstration of the shuttles were a component of the city's Smart City program. This was part of the 2017/18 Australian Driverless Roadtrip. The trial ran from 26 Feb until 3 March 2018.

actors: VEDECOM; Department of Transport and Main Roads; Queensland University of Technology; iMove Cooperative Research Centre; Ipswich City Council
initiative_description: Ipswich motorists are being encouraged to be among the first participants of the Cooperative and Highly Automated Driving (CHAD) pilot program in Bundamba. Up to 500 members of the community will have the opportunity to experience an on-road demonstration of automated driving, using the TMRs Level 4 connected and automated vehicle (CAV), known as ZOE2. ZOE2, a highly automated research prototype vehicle, will provide participants with a self-driving technology experience in action, navigating real traffic on suburban roads, around the TAFE Queensland Ipswich Campus at Bundamba during March to May.

actors: VEDECOM; Department of Transport and Main Roads; Queensland University of Technology; iMove Cooperative Research Centre
initiative_description: A Renault ZOE2 built by French research consortium VEDECOM in collaboration with TMR, the Queensland University of Technologys Centre for Accident Research and Road Safety, the iMove Cooperative Research Centre, and the Motor Accident Insurance Commission. The car was granted a permit to allow it to be tested on predefined public roads in the suburb of Shailer Park under the supervision of engineers, but had previously undergone extensive off-road testing at the nearby Mount Cotton Driver Training Centre in the lead-up to Tuesdays demonstration. The initiative was part of the Department of Transport and Main Roads Cooperative and Highly Automated Driving (CHAD) pilot programme.

actors: La Trobe University; VicRoads; Australian Road Research Board; Keolis Downer; HMI Technologies; Royal Automobile Club of Victoria
initiative_description: Melbourne's La Trobe University has detailed findings of what it called successful on-campus trials of Navya's driverless Autonobus shuttle. The Autonobus drove students around La Trobe's Bundoora campus as part of a trial until July 2018. The Autonobus passed every test it went through, including safety, technical, operational, and passenger testing on a pre-programmed route, and interacting with pedestrians, cars, buses, and cyclists, according to Dean Zabrieszach, CEO of project partner HMI Technologies. The project, was partly funded through a $375,000 Victorian Government Smarter Journeys Programme grant and lasted for one year.

actors: University of Western Australia; EasyMile; Telstra
initiative_description: The University of Western Australia (UWA) partnered with EasyMile and Telstra to trial EasyMile's shuttle for nine days. The aim of the project was to assess the possibility of using this type of technology as an on-site sustainable transport link. UWA Business School staff and students from UWAs Planning and Transport Research Centre will also tap into the trial, using surveys and experiments to explore the impact of the technology on potential users. Pickup points for passengers on Open Day this Sunday 12 August will be at Reid Library at the centre of the Crawley campus and at UWA Business School, which is located at the south-east corner of campus. The bus is equipped with wheelchair access. The bus will not drive on public roads during the UWA trial.

actors: Redland City Council; Royal Automobile of Queensland (RACQ)
initiative_description: The Redlands Coast Smart Mobility Trial was a joint initiative between Redland City Council and RACQ. From 26 November 2020 until 26 June 2021, the autonomous vehicle connected the popular destinations of Raby Bay Harbour with Raby Bay Foreshore Park, providing a free public passenger service along Masthead Drive.

actors: Redland City Council; Royal Automobile of Queensland (RACQ)
initiative_description: Redland City Council initiated the six-month trial with a shuttle supplied by the Royal Automobile Club of Queensland (RACQ). The shuttle was free to ride and operated each weekday in conjunction with ferries to the mainland. Redland and RACQ used Karragarra Island as a test location due to a lack of local public transit options.

actors: EasyMile; Renmark Paringa Council; SAFE Automation; Flinders University; Department of Infrastructure, Planning and Logistics (Government of South Australia)
initiative_description: A two-year project provided first and last-mile connectiving services linking the various elements of the community and also providing mobility for the elderly and tourists. The 4.5 km route connected the areas of the Renmark CBD including the riverfront, the Renmark Club, aged care villages, swimming pool, library and the shopping precinct. The trial also complemented existing regional bus and local transport services.

actors: EasyMile; TransDev; Telstra; Sunshine Coast Council
initiative_description: Mooloolaba was the first South East Queensland location to host free public demonstration trips for visitors and residents on the Sunshine Coast. The trips ran daily from 14-16 December between 10am-3pm. The shuttle ran down The Esplande. This was part of the 2017/18 Australian Driverless Roadtrip.

actors: Transport for NSW; NRMA; HMI Technologies; Telstra; Sydney Olympic Park Authority; IAG
initiative_description: During 2017 to 2020 Transport for NSW partnered with HMI Technologies, NRMA, Telstra, IAG, UTS and the Sydney Olympic Park Authority to test and trial an automated smart shuttle at the Sydney Olympic Park precinct. The trial was carried out over three key phases with the later stages of the project seeing the self-driving shuttle carry up to 15 customers around precinct grounds, venues, and businesses.

actors: HMI Technologies; Christchurch International Airport; Christchurch City Council; University of Canterbury; Navya
initiative_description: HMI Technologies in partnership with Christchurch International Airportand with the support of the Christchurch City Council ran New Zealands first fully driverless vehicle trial. The public trial will incorporate a NAVYA ARMA electric powered autonomous shuttle vehicle operating on private roads of the Christchurch International Airport campus. The University of Canterbury's Human Interface Technology Lab were involved in identifying ways to improve human interactions with the technology.

actors: Ohmio Automation; Christchurch City Council; Christchurch Airport
initiative_description: An Ohmio Automation shuttle owned by Christchurch Airport offered Christchurch residents the opportunity to test the shuttle at the Botanical Gardens for free. The rides started at the old Tea Kiosk, next to the children's paddling pools and playground. The development of the shuttle was supported by the Christchurch City Council who provided Ohmio with a grant of $50,000 from its Innovation and Sustainability Fund.

Christchurch Airport is trialling Ohmio Automation's Lift Shuttle as part of its ongoing AV trial. The shuttle travelled on public roads around the airport campus. Passengers were able to ride the shuttle for free with collection times outside the terminal at 8:00am, 10:00am, 12:00pm and 2:00pm, running from June 24 to June 28 2019.

actors: Ohmio Automation; Intelligent Transport System New Zealand (ITSNZ)
initiative_description: Ohmio Automation offered free rides on their Lift shuttle in Queenstown for two days. This coincided with a global forum on autonomous vehicles hosted by the Intelligent Transport System New Zealand (ITSNZ) at the QT Hotel. This was the first time in New Zealand, an 'autonomous shuttle' bus was used on an 'open public road'  Lower Beach St, which is still closed to traffic. A spokesperson for the Queenstown Lakes District Council says Ohmio submitted a Traffic Management Plan to the council to run the bus.

actors: Ohmio Automation; Waka Kotahi NZ Transport Agency
initiative_description: Ohmio Automation offered free rides in their Ohmio Lift shuttle for two days in Wellington. The shuttle operated on the waterfront between Circa Theatre and Te Papa Museum. Ohmio Automation are one of 24 recipients of Waka Kotahi NZ Transport Agency's Hoe ki angit?  Innovation Fund. They are working with Waka Kotahi to develop a new approval process for autonomous shuttles, the first step towards enabling them to operate on New Zealand streets.

address: Coffs Harbour, New South Wales, Australia
actors: Transport for NSW; Busways; Coffs Harbour City Council; EasyMile; Via
initiative_description: The trial was a NSW Government initiative, being led in partnership between Transport for NSW, Busways, Coffs Harbour City Council and EasyMile. This project explored how connected and automated vehicle (CAV) technology can improve transport mobility and service outcomes for customers. Phase 1 operated at the Coffs Harbour Marina, travelling along the Northern Breakwall to Muttonbird Island. Phase 2 operated in Marian Grove Retirement Village to test a more complex environment and the ability of AVs to address various mobility needs. Phase 3 offered plenty of opportunity for growth and development as the technology was tested through a range of use cases. The botanic gardens offered a closed but public environment for the project team to further test features of the vehicle. The Coffs Harbour BusBot trial is supported through the Smart Innovation Centre, Transport for NSWs technology hub established in 2016 to facilitate the collaborative research, development and piloting of safe and efficient emerging transport technology.

actors: Royal Automobile Club Western Australia (RAC WA); City of Greater Geraldton; Western Australian Government
initiative_description: During the demonstration, passengers boarded the RAC Intellibus outside the Geraldton Visitor Centre and travel on a 2.6km loop in the vicinity of the Geraldton Foreshore, Marine Terrace mall, the newly developed Town Square, Ghost Office and Rocks Centre, and the Museum of Geraldton.

The University of Melbourne has signed a three-year partnership with EasyMile. An autonomous vehicle that can carry 12 people with a maximum speed of 40 kilometres per hour has arrived on campus, but will be initially used for research rather than passenger transportation.

actors: Newcastle City Council; Keolis Downer; Navya
initiative_description: Keolis Downer launches a trial of autonomous electric shuttle made by Navya in Newcastle. The pilot project is part of the Federal Government's Smart Cities and Suburbs programme. The City of Newcastle won a grant of $5 million to undertake the trial. The trial autonomous shuttle bus will operate on a 2km loop from Wharf Road between the Watt Street and Nobbys Beach roundabouts on weekdays between 10am and 2pm.

actors: Royal Automobile Club Western Australia (RAC WA); City of South Perth; Western Australian Government
initiative_description: The RAC Intellibus is Australias longest-running automated vehicle trial, starting in 2016. The route starts at the RAC Intellibus Hub at the eastern end of South Perth Esplanade. The free 3.5km journey takes passengers west along the South Perth foreshore. The shuttle operates Thursday to Sunday.

actors: Curtin University; Cisco; Woodside Energy Ltd
initiative_description: Curtin University in Perth is the first educational establishment in Australia to trial a commercial driverless bus, and will use the vehicle as an opportunity to carry out further research in satellite navigation systems, road safety and mobility issues for people with disabilities. Paerata Rise, the largest housing development currently under construction in Auckland, is set to become the ultimate Smart Village with the creation of New Zealand's first community based private mobile network and an autonomous shuttle for residents. Ohmio, Think Robotics and Dense Air have partnered to develop and build this cutting-edge system that will provide on demand transport to future residents of Paerata Rise via a smart phone app. The self-driving shuttle system is a key element to the state-of-the-art lifestyle Paerata Rise will offer residents, as it will improve access between facilities such as park and ride spaces and the Paerata train station which is set to begin development in 2020.

actors: Shenzhen Bus Group; Haylion Technologies; National Intelligent Transport Systems Center of Engineering and Technology

Four buses serve a 1.2km route with 3 stops. For the Shenzhen Bus trial, a human driver is stationed at the steering wheel, ready to take over if the vehicle encountered a situation that it cannot automatically handle.

Macnica in collaboration with PerceptIn conducted an autonomous driving demonstration experiment using a newly manufactured compact mobility vehicle (macniCAR-01) betweem 21-24 November 2020. The demonstration took place in the Misakubo district of Hamamatsu City. This demonstration experiment was the first public road run in Japan using an ultra-low-cost autonomous driving system that does not use LiDAR and high-precision 3D maps in this region. Tajima EV's Gian (ultra-compact mobility) vehicle was combined with PerceptIn's autonomous driving system. The demonstration was conducted on a 2km route in the Misakubo district.

Macnica provided local residents with rides on a Navya shuttle along a one-way section of about 1.3 km. The route connected Hitachiota City Hall in the central area of Hitachiota City and Hitachiota Station. Macnica conducted a questionnaire survey on regional needs and social acceptance, and evaluated and verified the technical aspects related to the operation of autonomous driving shuttle buses. actors: Macnica; PerceptIn; Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism
initiative_description: Macnica in collaboration with PerceptIn provided an autonomous mobility service between November 2019 and March 2020. This service was offered as part of the Heijo Palace Historical Park Smart Challenge. Sponsored by the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, this initiative aimed to solve problems and create services for park users. The service was provided using an eight-passenger low-speed electric vehicle (LSEV). The autonomous driving bus, traveling at a speed of 7-8km /h, passed through three stops within the park and made a circuit around the park in about 30 minutes according to the operating schedule. Anyone can ride the 8-passenger bus free of charge on a first-come, first-served basis, and we conducted a questionnaire after boarding.

The vehicle was demonstrated on Chuo-dori between JR Yokkaichi Station and Kintetsu Yokkaichi Station, a route of approximately 1.2 km. actors: Renault Group; Dongfeng Renault Automotive Company; Wuhan Caidian Ecological Development Group
initiative_description: The first AV test zone was opened in Whuan in 2016. The zone consists of a 2-km lakeside stretch within the Sino-French Wuhan Ecological Demonstration City, a development stemming from a 2014 Sino-French agreement to develop sustainable districts in three Chinese cities. Initial tests were suppose to run for up to two years and involve a variant of the Renault Zoe EV, built in China under a Renault-Dongfeng joint venture. The Sharing Bus, an unmanned vehicle jointly developed by QCraft and Dongfeng Yuexiang, was unveiled on Wednesday. It will start internal trial operations between Chuanjiangchi Metro Station and Chunsun in the Wuhan Economic and Technological Development Zone (WHDZ), creating an unmanned metro transfer route based on vehicle infrastructure cooperative systems and exploring a new sustainable operation business model. The Sharing Bus is a fully unmanned vehicle without a traditional drivers seat. Relying on the Driven-by-QCraft, QCrafts self-developed automated driving solution focused on complex urban traffic scenarios, the Sharing Bus not only has 360-degree blind zone sensing capability, but also has full redundant design of sensors, computing platforms and other modules, which ensures the safety and reliability of unmanned driving to the maximum extent. In addition, combined with the vehicle infrastructure cooperative systems in WHDZ, the Sharing Bus has realized L4-level automated driving capability on open roads. It can drive safely and reliably on urban open roads at a speed of 20 to 50 kilometers per hour, and flexibly respond to all kinds of complex urban traffic scenarios.

On 23 October 2021, QCraft started offering local residents rides in a downtown area of Wuxi. Five robobuses were initially deployed along three routes, totaling 15 kilometres (9.3 miles). The pilot service covered about 10 square kms in the busiest portions of the city and connected major shopping centres and subway stations to residential properties. For safety considerations, the battery-powered vehicle travels no more than 50 kilometers per hour and only 18 passengers can fit inside.

actors: Waymo One; Valley Metro; Arizona State University
initiative_description: Autonomous robotaxis were deployed orginally as part of a two-year pilot program in Chandler, United States. The Valley MetroWaymo Automated Vehicle RideChoice pilot project started in September 2018. It involved was a partnership Waymo and Valley Metro, the Phoenix area's regional public transportation authority. In Phase 1 (employee phase) of the project, Waymos Chrysler Pacifica Hybrid minivans provided Valley Metro employees in the Chandler area a way of getting to transit park-and-ride lots from their homes. The service was largely targetted at providing a home-end first/last-mile connection for employees commuting to and from Valley Metro in Downtown Phoenix. Phase 2 provided first-and-last mile travel to Valley Metro RideChoice travelers, which covers groups traditionally underserved by public transit. These groups include paratransit-certified people under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and for older adults aged 65 and over. This Phase included service in communities within the Greater Phoenix (Maricopa County) East Valley areaChandler, Mesa, Gilbert, Tempe, Guadalupe, the Gila River Indian Community, and Ahwatukee. Waymo and Valley Metro hoped to learn more about how people use public transit and what role self-driving cars can have in connecting people to the buses, trains and light-rail systems found in cities.  The pilot ended in March 2020, partly because of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Valley MetroWaymo Automated Vehicle RideChoice project was a part of Valley Metros Mobility on Demand (MOD) Sandbox Demonstration, one of 11 MOD Sandbox Demonstrations funded by the Federal Transit Administration (FTA).

Rakuten completed a successful demonstration of delivering supplies via drone flight beyond visual range in the alpine village of Hakuba. This was the first time in Japan that a drone was used to deliver supplies in a mountainous region where the difference in altitude between takeoff and landing locations reached approximately 1600m. Hakuba, a popular winter sports destination for tourists in Japan, faces significant challenges in transporting supplies between mountain huts. Currently staff either carry supplies on foot or have them delivered via helicopter. The cost of the trips, however, is rising sharply and helicopters cannot be used under poor weather conditions. Trials were conducted from mid-August to mid-September along a route that is approximately 5km long, from Sarukuraso (1,250m above sea level) at the foot of Mountain Shirouma (2,932m) in Hakuba, to one of Japans highest mountain huts, Hakuba Sanso (2,832m), at the summit and the Hakubadake Chojoshukusha hut (2,730m). Implementing drones shrunk delivery time to around 15 minutes, as compared to traveling seven hours by foot. The drone delivered peaches, pears, and other supplies weighing up to 5kg from the foot of the mountain to the destination without tarnishing their quality.
