actors: Skye Air; Dunzo; Government of Telangana; World Economic Forum
initiative_description: Delivery drones were trialled in Vikarabad, Telangana, India. The aim of the trial was to enable faster and efficient healthcare logistics by delivering packages within 12km range in an expected time of 18 minutes. The six-day trial commenced on 20 Sep and ran until 25 September. Skye Air, an Indian drone company, worked in collaboration with delivery start-up Dunzo, to complete the trial. Skye Air indicated that they would be conducting around 50 flights over the course of the trial. Both organisations were part of the the Dunzo MedAir consortium funded by the Government of Telanganas Medicines from the Sky project. This project arose after the Telangana government received the permission to use drones within the visual line of sight (VLOS) for experimental delivery of COVID-19 vaccines from the Ministry of Civil Aviation (MoCA) for one year. Following this, the state government, in partnership with the World Economic Forum established several consortiums to demonstrate trials of delivery of vaccines and medicine using drones.

Delivery drones are being trialled in Uttarkashi, Uttarakhand, India. The aim of the trial is to enable faster and efficient diagnostic services for citizens living in Uttarkashis hilly terrain, with limited connectivity. The drone pilot flights from Uttarkashi Skye Hub to Dehradun Skye Hub will reduce the delivery time, which takes 6-8 hours by road and 12 hours during a landslide to only 1.5 hours. The long-term trial is a partnership between Redcliffe Labs, a diagnostics service provider and drone delivery logistics company, Skye Air Mobility. The trial commenced on the 6 December 2022.

Delivery drones were trialled in Bangalore, Karnataka, India. The 7-day trial was a partnership between Aster DM Healthcare, a healthcare company, and drone delivery logistics company, Skye Air Mobility. Drones carried medicines and diagnostic samples from Aster RV Hospital (JP Nagar) to Aster Clinics located within Bengaluru city. A designated Skye Air cold chain professional loaded the medicine and diagnostic sample in a temperature-controlled payload box. The payload box was then loaded in the drone which drone pilots at the command centre then directed along a predetermined route to a fixed landing pad. The trial ran from 14-20 May 2022.

actors: Skye Air; Bluedart; Government of Telangana; World Economic Forum; HealthNet Global of Apollo Hospitals; NITI Aayog
initiative_description: Delivery drones were trialled in Vikarabad, Telangana, India. The aim of the trial was to discover how life-saving medical items such as blood, vaccines and medicines can be delivered more rapidly compared to by road. Drones delivered vaccine payloads of 1.5 Kgs to 3km distance within 7 minutes. Flights occurred between the Police Parade Ground and a local PHC. The trial was done using state of the art temperature-controlled box maintaining 2-8 degrees Celsius. The payload box was then loaded in the drone which drone pilots at the command centre then directed along a predetermined route to a fixed landing pad. The month-long trial commenced on 11 Sep and ran until mid-October. Skye Air, an Indian drone company, worked in collaboration with delivery start-up Blue Dart, to complete the trial. Both organisations were part of the the Blue Dart Med Express consortium funded by the Government of Telanganas Medicines from the Sky project. This project arose after the Telangana government received the permission to use drones within the visual line of sight (VLOS) for experimental delivery of COVID-19 vaccines from the Ministry of Civil Aviation (MoCA) for one year. Following this, the state government, in partnership with the World Economic Forum established several consortiums to demonstrate trials of delivery of vaccines and medicine using drones.

Delivery drones were trialled in Gurugram, Haryana, India. The trial was undertaken as part of a collaboration between Skye Air Mobility, a drone delivery service, and Curefoods, a cloud kitchen startup. During the trials, the drones carried frozen food from Curefoods warehouse in Jhund Sarai in Gurugram to its kitchen outlet at Golf Course Road. The testing involved up to six flights each day, with each drone carrying a payload of 5 kg in temperature-controlled boxes that kept the frozen food fresh by maintaining a minus 20-degree temperature. The trial ran from 25-31 July 2022.

Delivery drones were trialled in Kolkata, West Bengal, India. The trial was undertaken as part of a collaboration between Skye Air Mobility, a drone delivery service, and Flipkart Health, the healthcare vertical of e-commerce Flipkart. The pilot operated a hub-and-spoke model, with medical supplies delivered from Flipkart's warehouse to its over-the-counter outlets (OTCs) across Kolkata. During the 15-day pilot, Skye Airs two drones carried 3 kgs (20-30 packages) of medicines per flight, at a maximum distance of 16 km. The drones took approximately 26 flights on an average, travelling back and forth from OTCs to the warehouse. The trial ran from 24 August- 08 September 2022.
